p: Even though thermal stability was the main factor explaining gene flow patterns in M. subnitida, temperature annual range and forest cover were highly correlated, so we could not disentangle the relative contribution of each. Our work is nevertheless the first to reveal a significant effect of forest cover on stingless bee gene flow, a long‐standing expectation for this group of bees with restricted dispersal (Jaffé, Pope, et al., 2016). Reduced gene flow across deforested areas was only found in one other tropical organism so far (Monteiro et al., 2019), namely the army ant Eciton burchelli Westwood, 1842 (Pérez‐Espona, McLeod, & Franks, 2012). Interestingly, these army ants exhibit striking life history similarities with stingless bees, as queens are permanently wingless and thus show a restricted dispersal (Jaffé, Moritz, & Kraus, 2009). Forested areas thus seem important dispersal corridors for this stingless bee, which could facilitate the migration toward higher elevations predicted under climate change (Supporting Information Figure S6).
